message.content: Search the web for "Premiere Pro UXP add marker to clip" or "Premiere Pro UXP clip label color". If renaming clips isn't possible in UXP, what alternatives exist? Can we add markers with text, or change clip label colors to indicate different takes? Find available methods for visually marking clips on the timeline.

Based on my search, here's what I found about the Premiere Pro UXP API and clip label color changes:

## Premiere Pro UXP API and Label Colors

Premiere adds its own APIs on top of the base UXP functionality.(no content)The Premiere DOM APIs give you direct access to Premiere's document model, allowing you to access and modify projects — sequences, tracks, clips, and markers, work with media, control playback, and apply effects.

### Current State of the API

As of November 2025, Premiere Pro has moved to extensibility based on UXP (Unified Extensibility Platform). ExtendScript-based integrations are still supported, and the plan is for them to remain so through September 2026.

### Label Color Methods

From the ExtendScript API (which is the predecessor and may have equivalent methods in UXP):
- `app.project.rootItem.children[index].getColorLabel()` retrieves the project item's color label.

### Key Differences in UXP

An important difference between ExtendScript (and CEP) and UXP in Premiere is that all ExtendScript calls to Premiere were synchronous and blocked the Premiere UI. In UXP, method calls are asynchronous and do not block the UI thread. For a smooth transition, all properties (get and set) in the API were designed to be synchronous and do not need to be awaited.

### API Limitations

Extensions usability is limited by the Adobe Premiere API. Only items that have a source can be labeled, such as video, image, and sound layers.

### Resources for Development

- The Premiere Pro UXP API documentation is available at https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/
- You'll need a Premiere Pro BETA build available through Creative Cloud Desktop, and the UXP Developer Tool, also available for download through Creative Cloud Desktop.

For the most specific and up-to-date information about the `setColorLabel()` or equivalent methods in the UXP API, I'd recommend checking the official Adobe developer documentation directly, as the API is still evolving.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about adding markers to clips using the Premiere Pro UXP API in 2025:

## Premiere Pro UXP API - Adding Markers to Clips

### Key Findings

"In PPro, all markers and metadata associated with trackItems, are actually attached to the backing projectItem; it's not possible to have different markers and metadata for each trackItem." This is an important limitation to understand.

### Available Marker APIs

The Premiere DOM APIs give you direct access to Premiere's document model. These APIs let you "access and modify projects — sequences, tracks, clips, and markers," among other things.

From the TypeScript definitions, the UXP API includes:

`getMarkers(markerOwnerObject: Sequence | ClipProjectItem): Promise<Markers>` - Returns the Markers object for a Sequence or ProjectItem. There's also `createMoveMarkerAction(marker: Marker, tickTime: TickTime): Action` to move a marker to a new time.(no content)`createAddMarkerAction(Name: string, markerType?: string, startTime?: TickTime, duration?: TickTime, comments?: string): Action` - This is the method to add a new marker.

### Current State of UXP in Premiere Pro

As of November 2025, Premiere Pro has moved to extensibility based on UXP (Unified Extensibility Platform). ExtendScript-based integrations are still supported, with plans for them to remain so through September 2026.(no content)An important difference between ExtendScript (and CEP) and UXP in Premiere is that all ExtendScript calls to Premiere were synchronous, blocking the UI while executing. In UXP, method calls are asynchronous and do not block the UI thread.

### Resources

- The Premiere Pro UXP API documentation is available at: https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/
- For UXP-specific discussions, you can also post in the UXP forum: https://forums.creativeclouddeveloper.com/c/uxp-for-premiere-pro/105

### Important Note

Markers and metadata associated with trackItems are attached to the backing projectItem; it's not possible to have different markers and metadata for each trackItem. This applies to both CEP+ExtendScript and UXP.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Based on my search, here's what I found about Premiere Pro UXP trackItem properties and methods in 2025:

## Overview

As of November 2025, Premiere Pro has moved to extensibility based on UXP (Unified Extensibility Platform).(no content)ExtendScript-based integrations are still supported, and the plan is for them to remain so, through September 2026.

## UXP TrackItem Properties and Methods

UXP (Unified eXtensibility Platform) is an integration framework built into Premiere and other Adobe Creative Cloud applications. It is powered by a modern JavaScript engine and offers the ability to access many Premiere functions at a programmatic level.

### Key TrackItem Methods

From the UXP API type definitions:

TrackItems have methods including `isDisabled()` which returns true if the trackitem is muted/disabled, and `createSetDisabledAction(disabled: boolean)` which returns an action that enables/disables the trackItem.(no content)Additional trackItem methods include:
- `createSetNameAction(inName: string)` - Returns an action that renames the trackItem
- `getMediaType()` - Returns UUID representing the underlying media type
- `getTrackIndex()` - Returns the track index of the track this item belongs to
- `getProjectItem()` - Returns the project item for this track item

### Audio TrackItem Specific Methods

`getComponentChain()` returns an AudioComponentChain, and there are methods like `createInsertComponentAction()` and `createAppendComponentAction()` for managing components.

### Getting TrackItems from Tracks

To access trackItems inside of a track, you need input parameters: `trackItemType` and `includeEmptyTrackItem` for the `getTrackItems` API.

### Selection Methods

`getSelection()` returns currently-selected clips as an Array of trackItems. Combined with `app.bind`, developers can get real-time events of what the selected item is.

### API Design Philosophy

In UXP, a method call is asynchronous and does not block the UI thread. For a smooth transition between the ExtendScript DOM and the UXP DOM, all properties (get and set) in the API were designed to be synchronous and do not need to be awaited.

### Sequence Editor Methods

The SequenceEditor class allows you to duplicate trackItem using an insert or overwrite edit method to a destination track. Target track and start time of trackItem is determined using an offset value from the original trackItem position.

### Current Limitations

There is no current API method (DOM, QE, CEP, or UXP) that can move an existing clip vertically between tracks.(no content)Additionally, the Caption API is still under construction, and there is no available API to access and modify caption properties yet.

For complete documentation, you can visit the official Adobe UXP for Premiere Pro documentation at [developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/](https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/).


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

## Overview

As of November 2025, Premiere Pro has moved to extensibility based on UXP (Unified Extensibility Platform).(no content)ExtendScript-based integrations are still supported, and the plan is for them to remain so, through September 2026.

## UXP TrackItem Properties and Methods

UXP (Unified eXtensibility Platform) is an integration framework built into Premiere and other Adobe Creative Cloud applications. It is powered by a modern JavaScript engine and offers the ability to access many Premiere functions at a programmatic level.

### Key TrackItem Methods

From the UXP API type definitions:

TrackItems have methods including `isDisabled()` which returns true if the trackitem is muted/disabled, and `createSetDisabledAction(disabled: boolean)` which returns an action that enables/disables the trackItem.(no content)Additional trackItem methods include:
- `createSetNameAction(inName: string)` - Returns an action that renames the trackItem
- `getMediaType()` - Returns UUID representing the underlying media type
- `getTrackIndex()` - Returns the track index of the track this item belongs to
- `getProjectItem()` - Returns the project item for this track item

### Audio TrackItem Specific Methods

`getComponentChain()` returns an AudioComponentChain, and there are methods like `createInsertComponentAction()` and `createAppendComponentAction()` for managing components.

### Getting TrackItems from Tracks

To access trackItems inside of a track, you need input parameters: `trackItemType` and `includeEmptyTrackItem` for the `getTrackItems` API.

### Selection Methods

`getSelection()` returns currently-selected clips as an Array of trackItems. Combined with `app.bind`, developers can get real-time events of what the selected item is.

### API Design Philosophy

In UXP, a method call is asynchronous and does not block the UI thread. For a smooth transition between the ExtendScript DOM and the UXP DOM, all properties (get and set) in the API were designed to be synchronous and do not need to be awaited.

### Sequence Editor Methods

The SequenceEditor class allows you to duplicate trackItem using an insert or overwrite edit method to a destination track. Target track and start time of trackItem is determined using an offset value from the original trackItem position.

There is no current API method (DOM, QE, CEP, or UXP) that can move an existing clip vertically between tracks.(no content)Additionally, the Caption API is still under construction, and there is no available API to access and modify caption properties yet.

Links: [{"title":"uxp-premiere-pro/src/pages/ppro_reference/types.d.ts at main · AdobeDocs/uxp-premiere-pro","url":"https://github.com/AdobeDocs/uxp-premiere-pro/blob/main/src/pages/ppro_reference/types.d.ts"},{"title":"Markers","url":"https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/ppro_reference/classes/markers/"},{"title":"The Premiere UXP API","url":"https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/"},{"title":"Solved: Help with the new UXP createInsertProjectItemActio... - Adobe Product Community - 15239302","url":"https://community.adobe.com/t5/premiere-pro-discussions/help-with-the-new-uxp-createinsertprojectitemaction-method-quot-script-action-failed-to-execute-quot/m-p/15239302"},{"title":"GitHub - AdobeDocs/uxp-premiere-pro-samples","url":"https://github.com/AdobeDocs/uxp-premiere-pro-samples"},{"title":"Offline Docs - Premiere Pro Scripting Guide","url":"https://ppro-scripting.docsforadobe.dev/print_page/"},{"title":"Solved: UXP: Razor tool and marking clipped sections - Adobe Product Community - 15547922","url":"https://community.adobe.com/t5/premiere-pro-discussions/uxp-razor-tool-and-marking-clipped-sections/td-p/15547922"},{"title":"Add markers to clips in Premiere Pro","url":"https://helpx.adobe.com/premiere/desktop/organize-media/apply-labeling/add-a-marker-to-a-clip.html"},{"title":"Premiere Pro: Working with Markers","url":"https://www.macprovideo.com/article/premiere/premiere-pro-working-with-markers"},{"title":"GitHub - AdobeDocs/uxp-premiere-pro","url":"https://github.com/AdobeDocs/uxp-premiere-pro"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about Premiere Pro UXP Markers `createAddMarkerAction`:

## API Signature

The `createAddMarkerAction` method has the following signature:
`createAddMarkerAction(Name: string, markerType?: string, startTime?: TickTime, duration?: TickTime, comments?: string): Action`

This method is used to add a new marker.

## Key Implementation Notes

When using `createAddMarkerAction`, you need to use `lockedAccess` and `executeTransaction` for the action to work properly. Community members have reported that following the documentation for the function itself isn't sufficient without these wrappers.

## Related Resources

1. **Official Documentation**: The Premiere Pro UXP API documentation is available at https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/

2. **Sample Panel**: Adobe provides a third-party sample panel in the premiere-api directory from their GitHub repository. You can build it by navigating to sample-panels/premiere-api/html in your console/terminal.

3. **UXP Availability**: As of August 2025, only Premiere Pro BETA builds support UXP plugins.

## Important Context on Markers

In Premiere Pro, all markers and metadata associated with trackItems are actually attached to the backing projectItem; it's not possible to have different markers and metadata for each trackItem.

## TypeScript Definitions

To see definitions, you can add TypeScript definitions to the .js file in which you are working. You can then see and use TypeScript definitions for Premiere Pro's UXP APIs in Visual Studio Code.

For a working example, I'd recommend checking the Adobe UXP Premiere Pro samples repository on GitHub (https://github.com/AdobeDocs/uxp-premiere-pro-samples) which contains sample code for working with the Premiere Pro UXP API.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about the Premiere Pro UXP ProjectItem setColorLabel and colorLabel API:

## ProjectItem setColorLabel API

The ProjectItem class in Premiere Pro UXP allows you to create an action to set color label to projectItem by index.

### Usage in ExtendScript/UXP

`app.project.rootItem.children[index].setColorLabel(labelColor)` sets the project item's color label.(no content)`app.project.rootItem.children[index].getColorLabel()` retrieves the project item's color label.

### Key Considerations

For projectItems, you can use `getColorLabel()` / `setColorLabel()`.(no content)Note: trackItems created from a projectItem will not have their label color updated; any new trackItems created from those projectItems will get the updated label.(no content)One can only change the label color of projectItems; there's no API to do so for trackItems.

### UXP vs ExtendScript

An important difference between ExtendScript (and CEP) and UXP in Premiere is that all ExtendScript calls to Premiere were synchronous, meaning they blocked the Premiere UI while executing. In UXP, a method call is asynchronous and does not block the UI thread. For a smooth transition between the ExtendScript DOM and the UXP DOM, all properties (get and set) in the API were designed to be synchronous and do not need to be awaited.

### Official Documentation

You can find more details in the official Adobe Premiere Pro UXP documentation:
- **ProjectItem Class Reference**: https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/ppro_reference/classes/projectitem/
- **Premiere UXP API Overview**: https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

An important difference between ExtendScript (and CEP) and UXP in Premiere is that all ExtendScript calls to Premiere were synchronous, meaning they blocked the Premiere UI while executing. input.prompt: Extract all methods and properties of the Markers class, especially createAddMarkerAction. Show the complete API signature, parameters, and any examples.
Extract all methods related to color labels (getColorLabel, setColorLabel, createSetColorLabelAction). Show complete API signatures, parameters, and examples.
List all marker methods and their parameters
List color label methods and parameters
Find all methods related to markers (createAddMarkerAction, getMarkers) and color labels (setColorLabel, getColorLabel). Show their complete signatures.

content.content:
# Marker and Color Label Methods

## Marker Methods

**createAddMarkerAction:**
```typescript
createAddMarkerAction(Name: string, markerType?: string, startTime?: TickTime, 
                      duration?: TickTime, comments?: string): Action
```
"Add a new marker" with optional type, timing, and comment parameters.

**getMarkers:**
```typescript
getMarkers(filters?: string[]): Marker[]
```
Retrieves all markers, optionally filtered by specified criteria.

## Color Label Methods

**createSetColorLabelAction:**
```typescript
createSetColorLabelAction(inColorLabelIndex: number): Action
```
"Create an action for set color label to projectItem by index"

**getColorLabelIndex:**
```typescript
getColorLabelIndex(): Promise<number>
```
"Get color label index of projectItem"

These methods appear across multiple object types (ProjectItem, ClipProjectItem, FolderItem) with identical signatures, supporting programmatic marker management and color-coded organization of project assets.

toolUseResult.result:
# Marker and Color Label Methods

## Marker Methods

**createAddMarkerAction:**
```typescript
createAddMarkerAction(Name: string, markerType?: string, startTime?: TickTime, 
                      duration?: TickTime, comments?: string): Action
```
"Add a new marker" with optional type, timing, and comment parameters.

**getMarkers:**
```typescript
getMarkers(filters?: string[]): Marker[]
```
Retrieves all markers, optionally filtered by specified criteria.

## Color Label Methods

**createSetColorLabelAction:**
```typescript
createSetColorLabelAction(inColorLabelIndex: number): Action
```
"Create an action for set color label to projectItem by index"

**getColorLabelIndex:**
```typescript
getColorLabelIndex(): Promise<number>
```
"Get color label index of projectItem"

These methods appear across multiple object types (ProjectItem, ClipProjectItem, FolderItem) with identical signatures, supporting programmatic marker management and color-coded organization of project assets.

Based on my search results, I found information about Premiere Pro label colors, but I couldn't find a definitive list mapping the specific index values 0-16 to their corresponding color names. Here's what I was able to find:

## Premiere Pro Label Colors

In total, Premiere Pro offers 16 of them.(no content)By right-clicking on a clip and selecting "Label", this brings up a list of about 16 colors to choose from.

### Key Information About Label Colors:

**Default Label Assignments:**
If you go into Preferences > Labels, you'll see what the default label colors are for imported media. Blue (Iris) would be Video with Audio. Purple (Violet) would be Video without Audio. It's purely for visual reference and has no impact on how the video is exported or anything like that.

**Using Label Colors via Scripting:**
For projectItems, you can use getColorLabel() / setColorLabel(). Note: trackItems created from a projectItem will not have their label color updated; any new trackItems created from those projectItems, will get the updated label.(no content)app.project.rootItem.children[index].getColorLabel() retrieves the project item's color label.(no content)setColorLabel(labelColor) sets the project item's color label.

**Label Color Sorting:**
A more accurate description is that Premiere sorts labels by blue first, then green, then red. I figured this out from the new file format Premiere uses to save label color presets.

**Classic vs. New Palette:**
Settings > Labels > Label Color Presets > Classic will restore you to the label colors from previous versions of PPro.

**Some Known Label Color Names:**
Based on the search results, some of the 16 label colors mentioned include:
- Violet (Video without Audio default)
- Iris (Video with Audio default)
- Lavender
- Rose
- Mango
- Forest
- Green
- Cerulean
- Yellow
- Tan
- Teal
- Caribbean

Unfortunately, the specific mapping of index values 0-16 to their exact color names is not well-documented in publicly available resources. Adobe's official scripting documentation doesn't appear to explicitly list these index-to-color mappings. You may need to test the `setColorLabel()` function with values 0-16 in ExtendScript to determine the exact mapping for your version of Premiere Pro.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.
